awd_titl_txt: Protic Acid Catalysis of Organic Reactions
awd_abstract_narration:
With this award, the Chemical Synthesis Program is supporting the research of Professor Jeffrey N. Johnston of the Department of Chemistry at Vanderbilt University to develop new protic acid-catalyzed reactions to form carbon-carbon and carbon-heteroatom (nitrogen and/or oxygen) bonds.  An emphasis continues with the identification and development of functional groups (e.g. diazo alkanes and azides) that can be activated toward carbon-carbon bond formation by protic acids without protonative self-decomposition.  Underlying the development activities is a study of the mechanistic pathways involved and the elucidation of factors leading to high selectivity.  This approach will secure a fundamental understanding of reactivity, and in so doing, provide a framework for broader conceptual application and development.  The development of diastereoselective variations of these reactions will be an emphasis of this phase, leading ultimately to their application in the synthesis of complex contiguous aminopolyols.  

This research aims to develop greener chemical methods to more rapidly and efficiently prepare chiral small molecules.  Successful development of the methodology will have an impact on synthesis in the pharmaceutical and agricultural industries.  This project also provides research training for graduate and undergraduate students and contributes to the development of a workforce in STEM fields.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Organic molecules constitute the vast majority of therapeutics, ranging in size over several orders of magnitude across the small molecule and peptide landscape. These molecules are the substance of all new therapeutics, tools whose purpose is to improve our quality of life. To an increasing degree, advances in energy capture, storage, and use are also enabled by complex small molecules used as modifiers for catalysts. Whether they be used to discover and develop innovative materials, or in the treatment of disease for therapeutic benefit, large quantities and access to variations are required. A small fraction of these molecules are available from natural sources, and chemical synthesis is the only means to access the remainder. The aims of this grant were directed at the development of new reactions to provide access to the aminopolyol class of molecules. Since these are considered to be one of the most complex, this is a grand challenge. To address this in part, several new reactions were developed for this purpose, including the Brønsted acid-catalyzed aza-Darzens reaction and the Brønsted acid promoted azide-alkene cycloaddition reaction. The latter was applied to an aminopolyol small molecule target known as (+)-zwittermicin A that has been shown to exhibit antibiotic activity. Substantial progress toward the chemical synthesis of this tool has been made. On another front, a new complexity-building reaction was discovered in which a simple olefin and an amine (both inexpensive petrochemical products) can productively combine to create diamines. Diamines are common building blocks for general chemical synthesis.

The intellectual merit of this work includes the discovery of new chemical reactivity of otherwise common chemical functionality: alkenes, azides, amines, and diazomethane derivatives. A key aspect of our work is the study of relative stereocontrol in these reactions in order to produce isomerically pure products in high yield.

The broader impact of this work from the standpoint of scholarship is represented by the impact that the discovery of new reactivity can have beyond the basic sciences. The methods we developed can be translated to materials development and medicinal chemistry to prepare building blocks for countless other uses. The new reactivity that we’ve characterized will also inform and accelerate future developments in chemical synthesis, typically using catalysts other than those used in our studies (strong Brønsted acids), but also achieving the goal to bring molecules more easily into the hands of those who probe their utility.

The broader impact of this work from the standpoint of human resource development is found in the training of the next generation of researchers and teachers. Postdoctoral scholars, graduate students, and undergraduates have all played a role in the development of this work while furthering their own education and technical skill development. They are now employed at academic institutions (research intensive, primarily undergraduate, and a state college) and research institute (international) where they teach (and research with) our future scientists and non-scientists alike.


Last Modified: 04/21/2016
Modified by: Jeffrey N Johnston
